turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You know what you just signed, Jeanne?  You just signed away my existence... For you I'm a lie, an illusion.  You see?  In the end, you were the one who abandoned me...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: You think you are ready now?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes, my lord.

turns.speaker: MAN
turns.text: Let's see.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: You know I'm always happy to see you, Jeanne, but to keep coming here twice, three times a day...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I need to confess.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: But you already confessed this morning...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I need to confess again.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: So... alright.  What terrible sin have you committed since then that can't wait till tomorrow to be forgiven?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I saw a poor monk without shoes so I gave him some.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: There's no sin in charity, Jeanne.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: They weren't my shoes.  Mine were too small.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Whose were they?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: My father's.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: I'm sure he'll forgive you.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: He already did, but I want God to forgive me too.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Jeanne -- if we were to ask forgiveness all the time, we'd spend our whole life in church.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Is that bad?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Well no, but... Jeanne, are you happy at home?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Oh yes... very.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: And your mother -- everything's fine with her?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Oh yes, she's... wonderful.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Good, good.  And your sister... Catherine -- she's still your best friend?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Oh yes, my sister's just... she's... wonderful.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: And what about your other friends... you don't like playing with them?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Oh yes, I play with them... lots...

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: So... everything sounds... wonderful?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Yes, it is.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Then... why are you here so often?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I feel safe here.  And it's where I can talk to him.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Him?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Well, I try and talk to him, but mostly he's the one who does the talking.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Who is this "he"?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: He never says his name.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: What... does he... look like?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Beautiful.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: And what does he say to you?

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: He says... he says I must be good... and help everyone... and take care of myself.  Do you think he's coming from the sky?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Perhaps... but wherever he comes from, I think you should listen to him, because it sounds like he's giving you very good advice.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: I heard about your sister, and I... understand your pain...

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Why did she have to die?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Only God knows the answer to that.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I know Jesus says to love our enemies but I can't -- I just want the English to burn in hell for ever and ever!

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: I realize your anger, Jeanne, but we must learn to forgive.  It's hard, but revenge will never bring about peace.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: Then what will?  And what will bring her back?  And why did she have to die in the first place instead of me?  Why didn't he take my life instead of hers?  It was my fault -- I was late -- she gave me her hiding place...!!

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Jeanne... calm down...!  Calm down, Jeanne!

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I don't want to wait for his call.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Jeanne, be patient.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I want to be with him always...

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Soon you'll be able to take the Holy Mass, and as you eat of his flesh and drink of his blood, you will be at one with him.

turns.speaker: JEANNE
turns.text: I want to be at one with Him now.

turns.speaker: BENEK
turns.text: I'm sorry, Mr Wladek, he wants you to stop.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Who wants me to stop?

turns.speaker: BENEK
turns.text: Why are you here, Mr. Wladek?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: It's like this... I...we...all of them.

turns.speaker: BENEK
turns.text: Someone you know?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: BENEK
turns.text: A beauty. Who is she?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: A singer. Her husband's an actor. I knew them well. Good people. I'd like to talk to her.

turns.speaker: BENEK
turns.text: Don't forget, Mr. Wladek, they hang them for helping Jews.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: This is my husband. Wladyslaw Szpilman. Marek Gebczynski sent him.

turns.speaker: MICHAL
turns.text: Oh, yes. I remember.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I'm going to get a doctor.

turns.speaker: MICHAL
turns.text: You can't, it's too dangerous.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I'll get Dr Luczak, we can trust him.

turns.speaker: MICHAL
turns.text: Dorota, don't be ridiculous, he's a pediatrician.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: He's still a doctor.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Hello.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I came specially to meet you today. I love your playing, but what a day to choose.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Who are you?

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: My name's Dorota, I'm Jurek's sister. oh! You're bleeding.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: It's nothing.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I nagged Jurek for weeks and weeks. And at last he gave in and said, 'All right, come with me tomorrow,' and so I came and they bombed the station.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You know something? Meeting you like that was absolutely wonderful.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Really?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes!  It was...it was unforgettable.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I've always loved your playing, Mr. Szpilman.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Wladek, please.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: No one plays Chopin like you.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Oh, Mr Szpilman, you're quite... quite wonderful.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Wladek, please.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Dorota!

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: I didn't want to come, I didn't want to see all this, but I couldn't stop myself.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: How are you doing?

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Fine, no, not really, they arrested my cousin, but Jurek says they'll let him out.  This is disgraceful.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Don't worry, it won't last long.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: That's what I said, it's so - it's too absurd!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'll see you...soon.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Wladyslaw Szpilman.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Dorota.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Come in! come in!

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Sit.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry - I was given this address. I'm looking for a Mr--  -- a Mr Dzikiewicz.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Michal Dzikiewicz. He's my husband.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I need help.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: He'll be back before curfew.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I've been in hiding. I need somewhere to stay.

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: He'll be here soon.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: How long have you been married?

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Just over a year.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: And how's Yurek?

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Dead.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: When's your baby due?

turns.speaker: DOROTA
turns.text: Christmas.  This is not a good time to have children. But then...

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: What did I tell you?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What are you doing?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Will I still be able to play?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Let's find out.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Let me see this.

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: Doesn't it say we have to provide these armbands ourselves? Where will we get them?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: To tell you the truth, I thought it would be worse.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: How will we sleep?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: For what? For my tie?

turns.speaker: FATHER
turns.text: American Jews, and there's lots of them, what have they done for us? What do they think they're doing? People here are dying, haven't got a bite to eat. The Jewish bankers over there should be persuading America to declare war on Germany!

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: It's not going to be very comfortable.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'll be fine.

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: You'll have to stay here until tomorrow afternoon.

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: Must feel better this side of the wall.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes, but sometimes I'm still not sure which side of the wall I'm on.

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: Here.

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: Get your things together, you have to leave!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: I'm on the run!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: The Gestapo found our weapons. They've arrested Janina and Andrzej. They're bound to find out about this place, too - you must get away at once.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Where do you want me to go?  Look at me. No, no, I'm not leaving. Can't I take my chances here?

turns.speaker: GEBCZYNSKI
turns.text: That's your decision.  But when they storm the flat, throw yourself out of die window - don't let them get you alive. I have poison on me, they won't get me alive either!

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: Have you seen this?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What, I'm working, what?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's happened?

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: Oh my God, it's terrible, you've got to do something, oh my God!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Calm down, what, what is it?

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: They're hunting people on the streets. They've picked up Henryk.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Halina?

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Funny time to say this.

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: wish I knew you better.

turns.speaker: HALINA
turns.text: Thanks.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Henryk's in there.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: I haven't seen him.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Believe me, they've picked him up.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Tough luck.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Can you help?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Oh, you need me now, yes, now you need me!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Can you help us?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: It costs.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I've no money.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Then there's nothing I can do. He should've joined us when I gave him the chance..

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yitzchak, they told me you had influence.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Who told you?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: People I know. They said you're an important man.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: We're recruiting.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Who's recruiting?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Don't be clever with me, Henryk. I've come here as a friend. They're bringing Jews in from all over the country. Soon there'll be half a million people in the ghetto. We need more Jewish police...

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Oh? More Jewish police? You mean you want me to wear a cap like yours, beat up Jews with my truncheon and catch the Gestapo spirit. I see!

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Someone's got to do it, Henryk.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: But why me? I thought you only recruited boys with rich fathers. Look at my father, look at us, I mean...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Yes, I'm looking at you and that's why I'm here. Your whole family can have a better life. You want to go on struggling for survival, selling books on the street?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Yes, please.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: I'm doing you people a favour. And what about you, Wladek? You're a great pianist. And we've got an excellent police jazz band. They'd welcome you with open arms. Join us. You've got no work...

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: And suppose they take the table away?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: What d'you mean, take the table away?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: The Germans go into Jewish homes and they just take what they want, furniture, valuables, anything.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Do they?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: What's this about?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Sit down, have tea, I'll start lunch when the girls get back.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: And, please, tonight, for once, I don't want anything bad talked about. Let's enjoy our meal.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Okay, then I'll tell you something funny. You know who I mean by Dr. Raszeja.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Henryk, I said nothing bad.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: What's the matter with you all? Have you lost your sense of humour?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Boys, boys...

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Your work, yes, playing the piano for all the parasites in the ghetto, they don't give a damn about people's sufferings, they don't even notice what's going on around them!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: They bombed us, we're off the air.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Warsaw's not the only radio station.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Mama, that was a great dinner.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: It certainly was.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: No, no. Listen, I've been thinking --

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: That makes a change.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: You know what we do? We use psychology.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: We use what?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: We leave the money and the watch on the table. And we cover it like this.  In full view. The Germans will search high and low, I promise you, they'll never notice it.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Of course they'll notice it. But look--  This is a good place for something.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: A good place for what?  He's insane!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Just shut up.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: But...they won't get all of us... we'll...it's too small...there's four hundred thousand of us in Warsaw!

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: No. Three hundred and sixty thousand, so it'll be easy.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You sell anything?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Just one. Dostoevsky. The Idiot. Three zlotys.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: That's better than yesterday.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Three lousy zlotys. And there are people here making millions.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: You don't know, believe me. They bribe the guards. The guards turn a blind eye. They're bringing in cartloads, food, tobacco, liquor, French cosmetics, and the poor are dying all around them and they don't give a damn.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: It's not funny.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Well, you know what's funny? You're funny with that ridiculous tie.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What are you talking about, my tie? What's my tie got to do with anything? I need the tie for my work.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: You go to Heller, did I ask you to talk to him?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You're out, aren't you?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Did you beg, did you grovel to that piece of shit, that cockroach?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I didn't grovel, I asked him to help.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: What did you pay him?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Pay him? With what? With what could I pay him? Every zloty I earn we spend on food!

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: I can look after myself!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: They were taking you away.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: It's nothing to do with you. It's me they wanted, not you. Why do you interfere in other people's business?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You're mad, that's your trouble, you're mad.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: That's also my business.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's the matter? Are you sick?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Hungry.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's that mean, no employment certificate?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: You have to have an employment certificate to work for one of the German firms in the ghetto, otherwise...

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Otherwise what?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: You'll be deported.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What are you reading?

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: 'If you prick us, do we not bleed? If you tickle us, do we not laugh? If you poison us, do we not die? And if you wrong us, shall we not revenge?'

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Very appropriate.

turns.speaker: HENRYK
turns.text: Yes, that's why I brought it.

turns.speaker: JANINA
turns.text: No one thought they'd hold out so long.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: should never have come out. I should've stayed there, fought with them.

turns.speaker: JANINA
turns.text: Wladek, stop that. It's over now. Just be proud it happened. My God, did they put up a fight.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes, so did the Germans.

turns.speaker: JANINA
turns.text: They're in shock. They didn't expect it. Nobody expected it. Jews fighting back? Who'd have thought?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes, but what good did it do?

turns.speaker: JANINA
turns.text: What good? Wladek, I'm surprised at you. They died with  dignity, that's what good it did. And you know something else?  Now the Poles will rise. We're ready. We'll fight, too. You'll see.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Ah, here. Today's news from the other side.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You're amazing, Jehuda.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: No, I'm a socialist. I have brothers everywhere. They bring me news and food. We care about our fellow human beings. Workers of the world unite.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: So, what's the news?

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: The Germans are advancing on Kharkhov.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I don't know why I come here every evening, it's always such bad news.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Bad news, you crazy? You have no world view, Wladek, that's your trouble. The news couldn't be better. The moment Hitler invaded Russia, I knew we'd be all right. Remember Napoleon. Same business. The Germans will freeze to death, please God.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Jehuda, give me something to do.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: You're an artist, Wladek, you keep people's spirits up. You do enough.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: But I want to help, I want to.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: You're too well known, Wladek. And you know what? You musicians don't make good conspirators. You're too...too musical.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: There are notices going up. The city's to be cleansed of undesirables.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: There are always notices going up.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Five hundred. You know how many people on average read one copy? Twenty.  That makes ten thousand readers. These will start the uprising. Majorek hides them in his underpants. And leaves them in toilets.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Toilets?

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: I thought you'd be off on tour, playing London, Paris, New York?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Not this week.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: I have to say you look terrible. What's the trouble?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You've heard the rumours they're going to resettle us in the East?

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Rumours, rumours, you take it all too much to heart, Wladek.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I've been trying to get a certificate of employment for my father. I've managed to get certificates for me and the rest of the family but I need one more for my father. I've been trying all the firms, the shops...

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Why didn't you come to me?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I didn't know you were in the certificate business.

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: I'm not, but Majorek is.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Can you help? I've no money...

turns.speaker: JEHUDA
turns.text: Please, don't insult us.  Can you do something for him?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Jurek? Wladek Szpilman.

turns.speaker: JUREK
turns.text: Wladek! How are you?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Fine, we're fine, thank you, and you?

turns.speaker: JUREK
turns.text: Fine, we're fine in the circumstances. But I can guess what you've called about. There's nothing we can do; they won't reopen the station--

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Yes, I know, but Jurek, Jurek...

turns.speaker: JUREK
turns.text: ...not even music, nothing, no radios for the Poles. But I'm sure you'll find work, Wladek, a pianist like you.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Maybe, maybe not, but, Jurek, don't be offended, I didn't call to discuss my future career.

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Puppydog, what d'you mean, you forgot?

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: What d'you think I mean, Kitten? I forgot, that's what I mean.

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: You know what? You treat me like dirt!

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: I treat you like dirt because you are dirt.

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Pig!

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: Cow!

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Pig!

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: Bitch!

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Dirty pig!

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: You're a dirty pig!

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Takes one to know one! Pig!

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: If I play like an angel, why don't you listen?

turns.speaker: PUPPYDOG'S VOICE
turns.text: I was listening, Kitten.

turns.speaker: KITTEN'S VOICE
turns.text: Liar, you fell asleep. Pig!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: How long have you been here?

turns.speaker: MAJOREK
turns.text: Since last night. I was pleased to see you.

turns.speaker: MAJOREK
turns.text: They're going to start the final resettlement now. We know what it means. We sent someone out. Zygmunt. A good man. His orders were to follow the trains out of Warsaw. He got to Sokolow. A local railwayman told him the tracks are divided, one branch leading to Treblinka. He said every day freight trains carrying people from Warsaw forked to Treblinka and returned empty. No transports of food are ever seen on that line. And civilians are forbidden to approach the Treblinka station. They're exterminating us. Won't take them long. We're sixty thousand left. Out of half a million. Mostly young people. And this time we're going to fight. We're in good shape. We're organised. We're prepared.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: If you need help...

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Have a favour to ask. I want to get out of here.

turns.speaker: MAJOREK
turns.text: It's easy to get out, it's how you survive on the other side that's hard.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I know. But last summer, I worked for a day in Zelazna Brama Square. I saw someone I knew. A singer. Her husband's an actor. They're old friends.  I've written their names down. And their address. If they're still there. Janina Godlewska and Andrzej Bogucki. Good people. Majorek, you go into the town every day. Would you try and make contact? Ask them if they'd help me get out of here?

turns.speaker: MAJOREK
turns.text: I tried your friends. They're not at that address any more.  But.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: You made contact?

turns.speaker: MAJOREK
turns.text: Be ready to leave in two days' time. Same place as last night.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Thank God - Wladek! You're wounded.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: It's a little cut, nothing.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: I've been worried sick.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Pack, darling, get your things, pack.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Where are we going?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Out of Warsaw.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Out of Warsaw. Where?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: And what do you think you'll do while you're setting up a new line of defence? Wander round lugging your suitcases?

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Pack, Wladek, there's no time.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'm not going anywhere.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: No, no, no, I'm staying put. If I'm going to die, I prefer to die at home.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: God forbid!

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'm sorry, I did my best, I thought the certificates would save us all.

turns.speaker: MOTHER
turns.text: Stop it, Wladek.

turns.speaker: SZALAS
turns.text: You don't remember me, Mr. Szpilman?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: No, I don't think so?

turns.speaker: SZALAS
turns.text: Warsaw Radio. I was a technician. I saw you almost every day.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Sorry, I don't remember.

turns.speaker: SZALAS
turns.text: Doesn't matter. You've nothing to worry about. I'll visit often.

turns.speaker: SZALAS
turns.text: You don't want to worry about that. My grandfather was jilted by his girl friend when he got jaundice.  In my opinion, jaundice is not very serious. Drink up.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Why didn't you come sooner? It's been over two weeks.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: What the hell are you doing?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I was... I was trying to open this tin.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Where do you live?

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: What's your work?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I am... I was a pianist.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: A pianist.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Where are you hiding?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: In the attic.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Show me.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's all that gunfire?

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: The Russians. On the other side of the river.  All you have to do is hang on for a few more weeks.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What's happening?

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: We're getting out.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Are the Russians here?

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I don't know how to thank you.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Don't thank me. Thank God. It's His will that we should survive. Well. That's what we have to believe.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: What about you?

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: I've got another one.  Warmer.  What will you do when it's all over?

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: I'll play the piano again. On Polish radio.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Tell me your name. I'll listen out for you.

turns.speaker: SZPILMAN
turns.text: Szpilman.

turns.speaker: THE GERMAN CAPTAIN
turns.text: Szpilman.  Good name for a pianist.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Watch your feet!

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: Watch your feet!

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Careful! Watch his hand.

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: Watch his hand

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Well you stopped combing your hair, which is a good thing, it was looking over done.  You see these are the slits that the heads will go through, show him Nessie ... they'll be dead, the Reverend is going to use animal blood, no doubt it will be very dramatic. Tea!

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: It will be very dramatic.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: I can't imagine a fate worse than being dumb. Turn around.

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: To be deaf?

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Oh yes, dear too - TERRIBLE! AWFUL!"'

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Ohhh, it's so dark, it's like a dank cave.

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: Yes, like a cave.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Ohh no, it makes my skin creep!

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: We have just come from George Banes' and they have taken him over. It is no wonder he is leaving, he has got in too deep with the natives. They sit on his floor as proud as Kings, but without a shred of manners.

turns.speaker: NESSIE
turns.text: ... without a shred of manners.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: What would you think if someone played a kitchen table like it were a piano?

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Like it were a piano?

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: It's strange isn't it? I mean it's not a piano, it doesn't make any sound.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: I knew she was mute, but now I'm thinking it's more than that. I'm wondering if she's not brain affected.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: No sound at all?

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: No, it was a table.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Well, she was very violent with the gown. She tore off a chunk of lace. if hadn't been there I'd have sworn she'd used her teeth

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Oh, yes, yes of course, a concern.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: There is something to be said for silence

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Oh indeed. Cotton'.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: And with time she will, I'm sure, become affectionate.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Certainly, there is nothing so easy to like as a pet and they are quite silent.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: How are the lessons going? ADA nods enthusiastically. He's getting on all right? ADA nods again Good.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: That is good, yes.

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: He is quite altered, as if they had been trying some native witchcraft on him. Well tomorrow or the day after he will be gone.

turns.speaker: STEWART
turns.text: Baines is packing up?

turns.speaker: AUNT MORAG
turns.text: Well he has NOTHING to pack, but he is leaving. And it is just as well; Nessie has foolishly grown an affection for him ... we have had some tears
